issue.title: TSC/TSR: evaluation functionality and interface to losses/metrics

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
implementation of rudimentary evaluation functionality, should include:
- computation of methods' predictions on test set, after training on training set
- computation of common average and aggregate losses/scores for classification and regression
- interface to metrics/scoring functionality as in sklearn
- at first, preliminary design of the above

Note: *not* full-blown orchestration and experiment management

Conditional on https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/2 since calls the estimator interface which needs to be consolidated first.

issue.title: TSC/TSR: sklearn-like grid search tuning wrapper for TSC/TSR

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
wrapper which implements grid search tuning for TSC/TSR methods

interface should be exactly as GridSearchCV in sklearn except for the TSC/TSR use case, i.e.:
- wrapper method with constructor initialization
- lazy use of data, only in tuned method's fit/predict

Conditional on https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/3 and a "proper" hyper-parameter interface in https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/2 since calls evaluation per hyper-parameter choice in grid

issue.title: TSC/TSR: interface favourite UEA algorithms

labels.name: interfacing algorithms
labels.description: Interfacing existing algorithms/estimators for other packages

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Interface UEA algorithms from their dedicated module.

Obviousuly conditional on https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/9, the algorithms implemented, and https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/2, the predictor-estimator interface implemented.

issue.title: TSC/TSR: orchestration/benchmarking framework

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Worfklow automation, method evaluation, benchmarking and post-hoc analyses
Should be straightforward (but slightly tedious) by adapting mlaut framework interface

Conditional on evaluation framework https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/3 which in turn is conditional on prediction interface https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/2

body: Implemented TSR/TSC dummy examples, inheriting from sklearn baseEstimator. Also included some test cases with CI scripts. All relevant code is available in the "light" branch. Would appreciate feedback - probably better to discuss more in the corresponding slack channel.

Just reviewed it - this is great and more or less what I had in mind for the light-weight interface.

Though, could we add some examples and tests?
Unless the estimator really "uses" the time series stored, we can just use sklearn - the Dummys probably don't even behave any differently due to duck typing and one could just directly copy their code.
In the CI tests you showed that there are no problems with time series which is good.

As examples *of estimators*, I would consider crucial at least one instance of classification and regression where the time series are made use of. Could we maybe just use xpandas to get a mean computed of the time series - or a bunch of quantiles, or anything similar, then apply any supervised method (maybe SVC or random forest) and wrap it? I.e., no abstract interface but just one example to see it working.
split heavy-weight/high-level off to #21 , low-level is closed

issue.title: [DOC]The problem with the transition from scikit to sktime, especially for data preparation.

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Describe the issue linked to the documentation

<!--
Tell us about the confusion introduced in the documentation.
-->
Hey, first of all , i'd like to thank you guys for the contribution made to time series analyze. If you want to make sktime more popular, the documentation's readability&understand-ability is so important, especially the topic like data preparation. Since most of us are  familiar with the pandas and scikit, the transition is quit important for us. 
 
I have a multi-variate classification task.
My dataframe like below:
![panel](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41810121/180977283-adca0d25-4e7a-4b6b-8aa9-5b34c34369eb.JPG)
Due to some reason,some symbol lost some days records, like  #1 symblol has 1000 dates rows while #2 symblol only has 500 dates rows. I want use last 11 lags to classify current label's value. For example, for the first row, I will take the OHLC from the date 2014-10-30 to  2014-10-19, to predict the date of 2014-10-30's label. 
First of all, I convert the pandas(multi-index) to sktime's mtype(pd-multiindex)
data=pd.read_csv('etf_labels.csv',encoding='utf-8',parse_dates=[1])
data.sort_values(by=['symbol','date'], ascending=[True,True],inplace=True)
data.set_index(['symbol','date'],drop=True,inplace=True)
y_train, y_test, X_train, X_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, X, test_size=30)
# fit
hc2.fit(X_train, y_train)

ValueError: y must be a np.array or a pd.Series, but found type: <class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>

if change y_train to y_train.values
hc2.fit(X_train, y_train.values)
then
ValueError: Mismatch in number of cases. Number in X = 1 nos in y = 2424

finally, i have read more than 2 days for the section of the data preparation, but still confused.
#### Suggest a potential alternative/fix

<!--
To enhance the document's readability and understand-ability, the detailed and complete example is preferable. 
-->
